title: How to Transform a Living Room from Ordinary to Extraordinary

steps.headline: Decide if you want to go custom.
steps.description: Rather than limiting yourself to the off-the-shelf colour choices, why not mix your own colour? Even if it's just adding white or black to one of their existing colours, a few simple tweaks can produce something unlike anything else in their colour repertoire - and unlike anything in anyone else's living room.

steps.headline: Find a colour of paint that is almost what you want.
steps.description: This could be a lighter or darker version of what you actually want, or a version with more or less of a certain colour mixed into it than you'd want.

steps.headline: Grab a store assistant for help.
steps.description: Ask if they'll either mix a new colour based on that colour, or if they'll alter an off-the-shelf tin of paint from the likes of Dulux, Crown and so on. They can be wary of doing this, so you might have to identify a colour and go elsewhere to get a new colour made up for you.

steps.headline: Test the paint.
steps.description: Once they've mixed up a tin - go home and paint a small swatch of the colour on your wall to make sure that it is the colour you want.

steps.headline: Order the colour you like.
steps.description: If you like it, arrange to get more of it made so you go ahead and paint your walls in a colour you're not going to see in a neighbour's front room any time soon!

steps.headline: Open your mind to art opportunities.
steps.description: Gone are the days of art being prohibitively expensive. There are now a number of art fairs and exhibitions that advocate affordable art. The definition of "affordable" varies from person to person, of course, and as such, even at affordable art fairs you will see some pieces with eye-wateringly high prices. Which is why you use art fairs as research opportunities, and then contact artists directly.

steps.headline: Look at the local art fair listings.
steps.description: See if you can find anything that sounds like it might specialise in reasonably-priced art.

steps.headline: Walk around and note down the names of any that you like the work of.
steps.description: Often artists will have their own separate contact information and websites, allowing you to contact them directly and avoid gallery price mark-ups.

steps.headline: Visit their websites and browse their personal shops, if they have them.
steps.description: More often than not, when you do this you'll find alternative colourings of popular prints of their own stores, along with leftover prints from limited runs - giving you more reasonably priced, limited-run prints to adorn your walls with.

steps.headline: Consider commissioning some pieces.
steps.description: If you have a specific idea of what you would like the artist to produce for you, you can even commission them to make it for you - a truly one-of-a-kind and (hopefully) extraordinary piece!

steps.headline: Explore some options for customization.
steps.description: Don't worry, you won't have to draw your ideal armchair or sofa on the back of a napkin and thrust it in front of a designer. Leave the core armchair or sofa designing to handcrafted furniture companies, and then build from that design. Even you choose a popular design, chances are your tweaks will make it truly your own.

steps.headline: Decide upon a core design.
Choose a fabric.
Choose which size of sofa or armchair you would like.
Choose the level and quality of stuffing you want on the back cushions.
Choose the level and quality of stuffing you want on the seat cushions.
Let the company go away and create it for you.
Go custom for curtains, too.
steps.description: Yes, curtains do inherently have to be customised to the dimensions of your living room. That being said, some makers of curtains are more helpful than others, some will give advice on actually hanging the curtains too - this is where it pays to talk to curtain makers face-to-face.

steps.headline: Identify a potential curtain-maker.
Meet with them to discuss your ideas.
Give them plenty of opportunities to overrule you and suggest hanging options that you might not have thought of - you might be surprised at the wealth of options available.

methods.name: Bespoke shelving, bookcases, cabinets and tables

steps.headline: Consider customization for other furniture, too.
steps.description: This is a costly option, and as with the custom sofa and armchair option, don't think this means having blueprints prepared before meeting with designers.

steps.headline: Identify a potential furniture designer.
Meet with them to discuss your ideas, maybe with photos and magazine cuttings of the kinds of furniture that you like.
Thumb through their portfolio and see if there are any past projects of theirs that you like.
steps.description: Don't be afraid of asking for something they've already done before, but in another colour, or with space for a larger television or fleet of games consoles.

steps.headline: Give them plenty of opportunities to overrule you.
steps.description: They may be able to suggest storage solutions and so on that you might not have thought of - you might be surprised by what facilities and options they have available to them, outside of what they publicise on their website.

text: Custom paints Decide if you want to go custom. Rather than limiting yourself to the off-the-shelf colour choices, why not mix your own colour? Even if it's just adding white or black to one of their existing colours, a few simple tweaks can produce something unlike anything else in their colour repertoire - and unlike anything in anyone else's living room. Find a colour of paint that is almost what you want. This could be a lighter or darker version of what you actually want, or a version with more or less of a certain colour mixed into it than you'd want. Grab a store assistant for help. Ask if they'll either mix a new colour based on that colour, or if they'll alter an off-the-shelf tin of paint from the likes of Dulux, Crown and so on. They can be wary of doing this, so you might have to identify a colour and go elsewhere to get a new colour made up for you. Test the paint. Once they've mixed up a tin - go home and paint a small swatch of the colour on your wall to make sure that it is the colour you want. Order the colour you like. If you like it, arrange to get more of it made so you go ahead and paint your walls in a colour you're not going to see in a neighbour's front room any time soon! Commissioned art and\/or exclusive prints Open your mind to art opportunities. Gone are the days of art being prohibitively expensive. There are now a number of art fairs and exhibitions that advocate affordable art. The definition of "affordable" varies from person to person, of course, and as such, even at affordable art fairs you will see some pieces with eye-wateringly high prices. Which is why you use art fairs as research opportunities, and then contact artists directly. Look at the local art fair listings. See if you can find anything that sounds like it might specialise in reasonably-priced art. Walk around and note down the names of any that you like the work of. Often artists will have their own separate contact information and websites, allowing you to contact them directly and avoid gallery price mark-ups. Visit their websites and browse their personal shops, if they have them. More often than not, when you do this you'll find alternative colourings of popular prints of their own stores, along with leftover prints from limited runs - giving you more reasonably priced, limited-run prints to adorn your walls with. Consider commissioning some pieces. If you have a specific idea of what you would like the artist to produce for you, you can even commission them to make it for you - a truly one-of-a-kind and (hopefully) extraordinary piece! Custom sofas and armchairs Explore some options for customization. Don't worry, you won't have to draw your ideal armchair or sofa on the back of a napkin and thrust it in front of a designer. Leave the core armchair or sofa designing to handcrafted furniture companies, and then build from that design. Even you choose a popular design, chances are your tweaks will make it truly your own. Decide upon a core design.  Choose a fabric.  Choose which size of sofa or armchair you would like.  Choose the level and quality of stuffing you want on the back cushions.  Choose the level and quality of stuffing you want on the seat cushions.  Let the company go away and create it for you.  Custom curtains Go custom for curtains, too. Yes, curtains do inherently have to be customised to the dimensions of your living room. That being said, some makers of curtains are more helpful than others, some will give advice on actually hanging the curtains too - this is where it pays to talk to curtain makers face-to-face. Identify a potential curtain-maker.  Meet with them to discuss your ideas.  Give them plenty of opportunities to overrule you and suggest hanging options that you might not have thought of - you might be surprised at the wealth of options available.  Bespoke shelving, bookcases, cabinets and tables Consider customization for other furniture, too. This is a costly option, and as with the custom sofa and armchair option, don't think this means having blueprints prepared before meeting with designers. Identify a potential furniture designer.  Meet with them to discuss your ideas, maybe with photos and magazine cuttings of the kinds of furniture that you like.  Thumb through their portfolio and see if there are any past projects of theirs that you like. Don't be afraid of asking for something they've already done before, but in another colour, or with space for a larger television or fleet of games consoles. Give them plenty of opportunities to overrule you. They may be able to suggest storage solutions and so on that you might not have thought of - you might be surprised by what facilities and options they have available to them, outside of what they publicise on their website.
